newsitem.title: MAURITANIA: Virus kills rare Mauritanian monk seals.
newsitem.headline: Virus kills rare Mauritanian monk seals.

text.p: More than 60 monk seals, one of the world's most endangered species, have been killed by a virus and not toxic algae as previously thought, researchers said on Sunday.
The dead seals were washed up on Mauritania's Atlantic coast last month near the port of Nouadhibou.

Mauritanian, Spanish, Dutch and Irish scientists, working with the national oceanographic and fisheries research centre, initially thought the seals had been poisoned by eating fish which had swallowed the algae.
The seals were part of a colony previously estimated at 150, living off the Mauritanian coast. Ecologists say the species numbers no more than 350 worldwide.
So called because folds of skin around their necks recall monastic dress, they are among the last members of the seal family living in temperate waters in the northern hemisphere.
Four baby monk seals were rescued and are being treated in the centre's aquarium in Nouadhibou.
An epidemic which came from a virus causing distemper in dogs killed at least 17,000 seals in northern Europe in the summer of 1988.
Dutch researchers said highly toxic polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) may have made the North Sea seals more vulnerable.
A study found that seals with high PCB levels suffered from major vitamin A deficiency and reduced thyroid hormones -- substances linked to the efficiency of the immune system.
